The crumbling foundations that have struck Central and Eastern CT have been a problem for many homeowners in my district, and Rep. Courtney’s. We’ve been working to pursue all avenues to help these constituents. Today, we were pleased to hear from National Taxpayer Advocate Nina Olson that her office has sent a request to the IRS’ Office of Chief Counsel for priority guidance to allow homeowners to apply for federal tax relief. We will continue to work with Ms. Olson in getting the IRS to agree to release guidance as soon as possible to help Connecticut homeowners. We thank National Taxpayer Advocate Nina Olson for her commitment to work with us on a path forward.

It is a relief that the effort to roll back the Affordable Care Act failed in the Senate, but now the real work begins to not just protect the ACA, but strengthen the health care system for all Americans. The failure of the Senate GOP to pass their repeal will allow millions to retain their health care. Yesterday, I along with, Brian Higgins and Joe Courtney, announced we will be introducing the Medicare Buy-In and Healthcare Stabilization Act to begin that discussion and propose ways to make the system work better. This bill will establish a new option for Americans between the ages of 50-64 to buy into the Medicare network and benefits, thus avoiding the increase in premiums that older Americans in this age group often face in the private market. Additionally, Americans (ages 50-64) who receive coverage from their employer and wish to buy into the program would have the option to do so, and their employers could continue to contribute to their premiums pre-tax; a win-win for those employers and employees.    We need to put our partisan squabbles aside, and work for the American people. I stand ready to work with my colleagues across the aisle in order to achieve quality, affordable and solution driven answers for our healthcare system.

The War in Afghanistan has been the United States’ longest running war, lasting for 16 years. It has been over a decade since the first Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF) was authorized by Congress in 2001. It is Congress' responsibility to debate and authorize of use of military force. As I have called for before, it is time for Congress to have this debate again. It appears the President and his advisors have given a lot of thought to his plan, but that thought should also be debated and shared in Congress. When it comes to putting our troops in harms way and all the ramifications of that entails, it is Congress who must authorize the power. This debate must include both the extent of the use of force and what the exit strategy is.  I would like to commend President Trump on his recognition of the sacrifices our brave men and women have made, but that is precisely why we need to make sure that we have a clear strategy. The President has laid out a plan, but did not mention an exit strategy and that needs to be debated. President Trump also pointed out that we need to address Pakistan, their involvement and our response in this conflict. I agree, but believe this needs to be a part of the congressional debate. It is time for my colleagues to unify our efforts in order to clear the safest path to return for our brave men and women home, as they deserve a thorough, debated plan with a clear strategy.

Today we held a hearing on determining eligibility for Social Security Disability Benefits in the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security. Millions of Americans rely on Social Security for basic income when they are retired, or if they become severely disabled and can no longer work. There is no other private plan on the market that can compare. At the moment, the average wait-time for someone to get an appeal hearing on their disability benefits is 600 days. That is unacceptable. Some applicants lose their homes, their families, or even their lives while waiting for assistance. The current challenge of this process is the lack of adequate resources to help the more than 1 million people who are still waiting to get their cases heard. Since 2010, the number of Social Security beneficiaries has risen by 13 percent, while its operating budget has effectively been cut by 10 percent. Social Security beneficiaries and applicants deserve better. In addition, it is time that we take common sense steps to expand Social Security’s modest benefits to keep up with the needs to today and to strengthen the program for future generations. That is why I have put forward a plan, the Social Security 2100 Act, that will expand benefits and keep the system solvent through the end of the century. I am proposing that we create underground tunnels for I-84 and I-91 that would bring the city together, return the Bulkeley, Founders and Charter Oak Bridges to boulevards, increase access to the riverfront, and allow us to repair our eroding levee systems.    Please come to this forum to learn more about the proposal and share your thoughts.
